title: What do Persians think of Alexander the Great? - Quora

response.answer_text: This idea of Greeks and Persians is romanticized mainly by Americans. It is another means to spin hatred for the “designated Boogyman”. Modern day Iranians do not think about, nor live in 300 BC. I suspect modern Greeks have bigger fish to fry as well. As far as invaders go, far more destrcutive and barbaric ones have crossed Iran’s path. That is apart of every ancient civilization’s legacy. The important point is how they survive the assault. Other than the dispicable act of buring down Persepolis, I’d say Alexander fully imbraced and assimilated into the Persian culture. Because of that, he is not the most hated invader. He married Roxana, daughter of a Persian novelty. He began to dress as a Persian man and ordered his Generals to so as well. It is quite clear that he had an obsession with Persia and lived the rest of his days within the Persian empire. Greeks were not pleased with his ways. Since this question is painfully redundant, I was compelled to provide some prespective.

Persians refer to him as Alexander The Accursed The Persians that refer to Alexander as ‘The Accursed' are the ones who are angry and embarrassed at the fact that a man in his early 20's, from a remote mountainous region on the outskirts of the Persian Empire, managed to wreck havoc and destruction upon the Persians, annihilating their armies and making the Persian King abandon his men and run away from battle, not once, but twice, until finally culminating in the destruction of the mighty city of Persepolis, as revenge for the Persian destruction of Athens over a hundred years prior. The Persians messed with the Greek bull and they got the horns. In a BIG way…
